article.headline: New Mexico 74, Cornell 65
article.story: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) -- New Mexico looked very much like a team tired of its pre-conference schedule. The Lobos, who open the Mountain West Conference campaign next week at Wyoming, won for the seventh time in their last eight games with a less-than-skillful 74-65 win over Cornell Friday night. Danny Granger had a double-double with 23 points and 12 rebounds and center David Chiotti had his best scoring game in a month with 17 points. They were the difference in a game in which the Lobos had 19 turnovers, the most since they committed 21 in the season-opener against San Francisco State. "We've been a little worn out coming off that game at Wake Forest and just waiting to bounce back," Chiotti said of the Lobos' only loss in the last month. "I felt a little sluggish ... and was waiting for my second wind. But it didn't come until the second half." New Mexico (9-4) never trailed but didn't shake the Big Red (5-7) until the Lobos converted three turnovers by Cornell point guard Ka'Ron Barnes into seven straight points that put the Lobos ahead 66-51 with just over a minute left. Granger hit a shot in the lane, Javin Tindall sank a 3-pointer and Alfred Neale had a slam dunk off Cornell's turnovers. "This was a challenge tonight," New Mexico coach Ritchie McKay said. "They never went away. But good teams find a way to win games even when things aren't going their way." Barnes led Cornell with 28 points and Cody Toppert, who played his high school career at Albuquerque Academy, added 20. Toppert hit six 3-pointers, including three in a row in the final minute, but by then the Lobos were safely in front. Toppert had trouble getting open against New Mexico's defense much of the game and ended up hitting 7 of 16 shots. He put up several airballs but knocked down some tough shots in the final minute. "I tried to look at it like any other game," said Toppert, a star at the private high school in Albuquerque and son of former New Mexico player Bob Toppert. "I feel like I handled it pretty decently, even though I would have liked to have shot better and had a few more drop." Chiotti and Granger, who combined to hit 14 of 21 shots, were to score inside after two of Cornell's big men, 6-foot-8 Stevan Marcetic and 6-6 Lenny Collins, fouled out within a six-second span midway through the second half. The Big Red also played without starting center Gabe Stephenson, who has a knee injury. Cornell stayed close on the 3-point shooting of Toppert and Barnes. Barnes had four 3-pointers and 19 points in the second half. "I think we overcame a lot," Cornell coach Steve Donahue said. "We're down six, with the ball with 5:24 to go in the game. But there were a lot of things going against us." Granger hit 7 of 10 shots and added four assists to offset his six turnovers. The Lobos' turnovers helped the Big Red stay in the game. New Mexico guard Troy DeVries had five turnovers and Tindall, the point guard, had four. Both teams slumbered their way through the first half. Cornell missed its first 11 3-pointers before hitting its last two of the half. New Mexico wasn't much better, hitting 2 of 11 shots from behind the arc en route to a 32-27 lead. The rim wasn't the only thing that seemed to shrink in this game. "It was like trying to catch an apricot instead of a basketball," McKay said of the turnovers.
